Q10: How could the system be more helpful?
Q12: What influenced your decision to make revisions to Draft 3?

Q10: The way I do revisions is that I address the higher order concerns first (content revisions) and then edit (surface revisions) once the draft is complete after several revisions. The guidelines for revising the second draft suggest instruct the writer to aim for more warm colors (content revisions). However, after the second draft, I would tend to think that the higher order concerns are, for the most part, addressed and there is more editing (surface revisions) to do in the third draft.
Q12:
Having time to think about how I could better support the argument. 

The fact that I had words to spare in the word counter.

Q10: The current system does a good job at classifying revision types but I had a hard time seeing how to use that information to better revise or understand my writing. It was a little bit helpful because it made me slow down and think about my revisions but I didn't think it told me anything I couldn't already see without it.
Q12: I reread the text that I wrote until I found things which I disliked or which seemed wrong. I would have liked to use the color coding to better guide my decisions for revision but I wasn't able to think of a strategy of how to use that information effectively.

Q10:
The system seems to work on sentence-level. However, I think revision could be made at paragraph-level. Many modifications may only mean to make an idea easier to understand.
Even though I tried to make more revisions under the influence of the quantity report (want to get a higher number), sometime I was confused if all the revisions will improve the quality of my writing or not. Are there any bad revisions?
Q12:
The system's statistics. Basically, after working through 2 drafts, I think I have put all of my ideas on the page. In draft 3, most of the time, I tried to make surface changes or try to clarify sentences.
I think with later drafts, some creative or high level suggestions (as I have when I write draft 2) will be more helpful. Because I can identify exactly what the current problems are.
Usually, I may not identify many errors from my writing but suggestion from an outsider will inspire me more.

Q10: Perhaps identify in the text what the bubbles correspond to.  It can be hard to identify what bubble corresponds to what part in the text.  Also perhaps allow a mode where writers can identify for themselves what type of change each revision was.  There were two places where my revisions were incorrectly labeled (in my opinion) because the system did not recognize adding a new paragraph or adding a new sentence (for example, breaking a long sentence into two).
Q12: Being forced to sit for one hour and make changes.  Normally I write in bursts and spurts, but I rarely force myself to sit quietly and write.  I thus felt compelled to read and reread numerous times and make numerous changes.

Q10: If it could point to the sentence in the essay or highlight it while revising it
Q12: Difference between content and surface made me decide to revise a few and add a few lines

Q10: In the 3rd draft it would be helpful to highlight the sentences that have been identified as surface, or content.
Q12: The minimal amount of content changes from drafts one, to two.

Q10: Differentiating between evidence from the article and evidence that the author provided. Putting an emphasis on content changes with a maximum word count. In general, most writing should be rich in content but also succinct, however the system did not encourage this.
Q12: Needing to add more content material and also being in the lab which forced me to spend more time on writing.

Q10:
"The system helps me to recognize the weakness of my essay."
I think I disagreed with the above statement because while it DOES tell me what revisions I have made and whether those revisions are superficial or not, it cannot tell me WHY. Like, why might this sentence structure be bad, or why is this specific argument bad, or why I should find another passage to quote from, or how to improve, or how to have a better argument overall. I think this speaks to the fact that in general this program is super cool and super great and definitely helps with the overall structure of revisions (I think I would have totally used this for my own personal revisions), it could never be used to help weaknesses from a total writing standpoint.
Q12:
Ummm, I think whatever sounded good? I think it also has to do with my method of editing (which isn't necessarily a good one) that I kind of read it top-to-bottom and see how it flows or where it's lacking.

I definitely didn't use the whole "you should add more yellow to it!" because what if I added more yellow in Draft 2? At which point can I say "I added enough yellow, now onto making sure that it flows which inherently will cause more blue to pop up!" I don't know if I'm overthinking this or not.

Q10: When I was done making revisions, I did not know what to click next. It would be helpful if at the end of each step, a message would pop up telling you what to do. Also, although it classified my revisions as surface level or content, I did not necessary know how to revise the essay yet again. Yes, we were advised to make more content revisions, but sometimes adding too much content can be overkill. My favorite part of this system was the mapping because it made it easy to track where my revisions were.
Q12: Since the tutorial said the person should aim to have more "warm" colors, I wanted to make more content revisions. I went back to the original text and found more information that could strengthen my writing. However, a few of the content revisions I made were marked as surface level. For instance, I added in that Google was the company making the cars, which I feel adds context and specificity, but that was considered surface level. Although I see how context revisions make the essay stronger, I also feel like surface level revisions, like grammar, are also very important and usually more frequent. Therefore, after my third revision, when I had more "cold" revisions rather than warm, I felt like the system thought I did not make enough revisions. However, I still feel like I was able to strengthen my writing.

Q10: The system could me more helpful when you have to confirm revisions. It gets confusing trying to keep up with which you confirmed and which you did not. Maybe when someone forgets to confirm a revision in the text, it could flash red so the person knows which revision was missed.
Q12: The warm and cold colors influenced me to make decisions. I know that I needed to add more content based information and the different colors helped me to do that.
I would usually revise my essay but I was influenced to make more content revisions because of the system.

Q10: It would be beneficial if there were suggestions as to how to change the structure of the sentences that needed revisions.
Q12: The feedback that I received in the previous draft from the system.

Q10: Id like more info on why my writing was shown to be surface vs content. I would like the ability to upload previous writings and revisions of them and see how the system goes about reviewing them so i have an idea of what the system is looking for/ the basis for its rationale before starting on a new writing assignment.
Q12: I wanted the paper to read better. The color coding gave me an idea of where i made revisions that worked/ where i made revisions that didn't.

Q10: It could compare the number of supporting evidence for each paragraph and highlight which paragraphs have weaker arguments.
Q12: There were many surface level changes for one paragrah which led me to make changes in that paragraph.

Q10: If it could tell what revision you made instantly. So that we know that what we intend to do matches with what our writing conveys.
Q12: I had lesser evidence to support my claim. Thus I added some more content.

Q10: Sometimes the system recognized my change as a content revision even though I simply added a semicolon and combined two sentences. It said I deleted the sentence in draft one and rewrote it in draft two, but I only combined the two sentences. The system could do a better job at recognizing when punctuation is being used and not recognize it as the user deleting the sentence. There were two instances in which it recognized it as a content change even though I made slight surface changes.
Q12: The differences in color between the content and surface changes helped. I felt motivated to include more content changes because I believed orange to be more significant than blue. By recognizing which revisions are which, the system encourages me to make more meaningful changes instead of grammatical ones. I felt influenced to include more content and evidence to my piece instead of rewording the sentences and trying to make it sound better. The system did a good job at emphasizing the difference between the two and the importance of content changes.

Q10:
Make the directions more concise: The introduction section before I completed the tasks informing me about the criteria for content and the criteria for surface level information can be more concise because I skimmed through the criteria because I thought it was much to read. Since, I skimmed through the criteria for surface vs. content level information, it is difficult to approximate 1) if the system indicated the revision purposes correctly and 2) if I trusted the system feedback.
2. One error with subject/verb agreement: I found an error with "elicit". It was supporting a singular noun so it should be "elicits"  but the system corrected me to keep "elicit" when I made the change.  It is cool that the system is able to recognize details even such as subject verb agreement and it is even cooler that it can decipher between content and surface level.
Q12: I wanted to minimize the amount of surface level and maximize the amount of content. Most of all I wanted to maximize being concise and clear because it makes it easier for any reader to decipher whether statements are content or surface level if the statements are concise and clear.

Q10: Be automatic instead of having you make revisions and then upload them.
Q12: I wanted to make as many revisions as possible so I could see how the system categorized them and helped me realize how I was making my writing stronger.

Q10: Maybe for the program to suggest examples of what to replace the content or surface areas with.
Q12: Lot of grey area in my draft

Q10: Allow drafts to be viewed side by side
Q12: How the sentences sounded

Q10: It would be beneficial if the system could identify grammar and spelling mistakes and offer suggestions for revising the mistakes. It would also be nice to have suggestions for wording changes to improve readability. It could also be helpful if the system identified content of the essay that supported the thesis statement. If the system were able to do this, then I would be more inclined to delete or modify the parts of my essay that did not directly support or relate back to my thesis. This would result in more content changes and as a result a better final essay.
Q12: I find I always have new ideas for how to revise my writing when I take a break from it and come back to read it again. I thought there were a few ideas I could clarify with revisions this time around to better support my thesis. I also made a few surface changes to hopefully improve readability after reading my essay again.
